contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox protected area | name = Pacific Rim National Park Reserve | iucn_category = II | map = Canadian National Parks Location.png | map_caption = Location of ''Pacific Rim National Park'' in [[Canada]] | x = 68 | y = 617 | location = [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]] | nearest_city = [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]] | lat_d = 48 | lat_m = 38 | lat_s = 10 | lat_NS = N | long_d = 124 | long_m = 46 | long_s = 09 | long_EW = W | region = CA-BC | area = {{convert|511|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}<br />marine: {{convert|221|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}<br />terrestrial: {{convert|290|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} | established = 1970 | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | governing_body = [[Parks Canada]] }} '''Pacific Rim National Park Reserve''' is a [[Canada|Canadian]] [[national park]] reserve in [[British Columbia]] made up to have with parks of three separate regions: [[Long Beach (British Columbia)|Long Beach]], the [[Broken Group]] Islands, and the [[West Coast Trail]]. The entire park encompasses {{convert|511|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}) of land and ocean. The park is characterized by rugged coasts and lush [[temperate rainforest]]s. The park is open from mid-March until mid-October. ==Geography== The park encompasses a thin strip of land located on the south-west coast of Vancouver Island. To the east of the park lies the [[Vancouver Island Ranges]] of the [[Insular Mountains]] and to the west is the [[Pacific Ocean]]. During fall and winter, the area is continually subjected to moist air masses from the Pacific Ocean. The presence of the mountain ranges causes the air masses to rise and deposit large quantities of [[Precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]], a phenomenon known as [[Precipitation (meteorology)#Orographic precipitation|orographic precipitation]]. The area averages over 3,000 mm (118 in) of precipitation per year, a key factor in producing temperate rainforests. During the drier summer months the area is sometimes covered in fog. Average temperatures range ==Long Beach==<!-- This section is linked from [[Long Beach]] --> [[Image:Long Beach (Pacific Rim).png|thumb|left|300px|Satellite picture of Long Beach.]] Long Beach is the most visited and most accessible of the three regions. It is made up of the coastal region from [[Tofino]] to [[Ucluelet]]. The primary feature in this area is Long Beach itself. The area also contains the Green Point campground, which has 94 campsites for both tents and small trailers. There are also numerous trails in this region, running through bogs and temperate rainforest areas. Other structures in the area include a ranger station, [[British Columbia Highway 4]], and Wickaninnish Interpretive Centre. This centre is the main educational centre in the area and contains exhibits about local wildlife, plants, native culture, and history. The centre also includes a theatre, restaurant, gift shop, and information desk. [[Image:Longbeach prnp.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Long Beach, 2004]] ==Broken Group Islands== The Broken Group Islands region is made up of over one hundred small islands and islets in [[Barkley Sound]]. The largest forested islands are Effingham, Turret, Turtle, Dodd, Jacques, Nettle and Gibraltar Island. The area is accessible only by boat, and is popular with kayakers. There are seven camping areas scattered on the islands. Campers should be aware that there is no fresh water available in the Broken Group Islands, so any water needed will have to be brought in. ==West Coast Trail== The [[West Coast Trail]] is a 75 km (47 mi) trail along the west-coast of [[Vancouver Island]] from [[Port Renfrew]] to [[Bamfield]]. The trail was built to aid in the rescue of shipwrecked sailors. Construction on the trail started in 1907 and by 1910 the "Lifesaving Trail" was complete. The trail was abandoned in the 1950s. By 1970 the trail was transformed into The West Coast Trail, a challenging trail that takes visitors along rocky beaches, through rainforest, and across sometimes rough and muddy terrain. The trail has been improved greatly over the years and can be traversed in 5â€“7 days. [[Image:West coast trail tsusiat falls1.jpg|centre|thumb|800px|Tsusiat Falls, a campground on the West Coast Trail.]] ==See also== {{Portal|Geography of Canada}} {{Commons category|Pacific Rim National Park}} *[[National Parks of Canada]] *[[List of National Parks of Canada]] *[[List of British Columbia Provincial Parks]] ==External links== *{{Official site|http://parkscanada.gc.ca/pn-np/bc/pacificrim/index_e.asp}} *[http://www.longbeachmaps.com/parks.html Long Beach trails information] {{National parks of Canada}} [[Category:National Parks of Canada]] [[Category:Parks in British Columbia]] [[Category:Barkley Sound region]]
